blogs.title: How to Improve Your Self Image
blogs.brief: How to Improve Your Self ImageHow to Improve Your Self Image
blogs.content:
How to Improve Your Self Image by Atul

It’s important to concentrate on your concerns.

When you don’t feel good about yourself, it can cause problems in your life. Here are some tips to help you feel better about yourself. Stop saying bad things about yourself and start looking at the things you do every day that make you a wonderful person. If you don’t feel good about yourself after spending time with someone, you need to cut back on the time you spend with them. Switch to neutral statements that don’t hurt you instead. Changing your look can give you a new lease on life and make you feel better about yourself.

blogs.brief: · Procrastination is a deadly disease. Procrastinating all day and night, just having the guilt of not completing our work, is another kind of pain. The pain which can’t be expressed Infront of someone but deep within we all know that it’s nothing, but we are procrastinating.
blogs.content:
How Procrastination is killing your life slowly and silently every day.

· Procrastination is a deadly disease. Procrastinating all day and night, just having the guilt of not completing our work, is another kind of pain. The pain which can’t be expressed Infront of someone but deep within we all know that it’s nothing, but we are procrastinating.

· Most of us have everything near us all the facilities, the internet is the best guider (if you use it correct then only) but we don’t do the work. Just delaying the work as much as it’s possible is procrastination. The Parkinson’s law says that how much time we give to a work that much time it will take. If we give 2 days’ time for work it will take 2 days, if we give 5 days’ time for same work it will take 5 days.

· Procrastination is a such problem for which the self-realization is the solution. Realizing that we must do the work at time. We can’t create the time the one who saves it, achieve the most.

· There are many reasons to Procrastinate but there should one strong reason in your mind which must push you all time. Motivation don’t work all the time but being disciplined will.

All you have read till now, for sure you might have read it before also. As it’s the time for execution we start to fail but this 5-minute rule has worked as a miracle for me.

5-minute rule

· It is a very simple and effective rule which personally I follow because of this I can able to overcome procrastination.

· It’s just very simple you must convince your brain that your gone work for only 5-minutes and after that you are free to do what you want

· Just think of 2 options

1) If you must study for 5-minutes and after that you will be free

2) If you must study for 5 hours and will be completing the chapter today.

Surely you will choose first one right. You are gone convince your brain that it’s all about just 5-minutes and after that you are free and start to do your work for 5-minutes you don’t stop after the 5-minutes but surely continue ahead. The main hitch is to start to work and after that you will continue. This is rule even suggested by Instagram co-founder Kevin Systrom he said that

“If you don’t want to do something, make a deal with yourself to do at least five minutes of it After five minutes you’ll end up doing the whole thing”.

Start loving and respecting your work.

· I just think it’s very important to love and respect your work because of it we can able to survive on this earth. The work which gives us identity, the work which makes us unique. We must defiantly love it and respect it I feel.

· We have just start to like the work which we are doing, and we should star enjoying it. As we start loving and respecting our work it become so easy to do it. My personal experience of doing the work when slowly I started loving and respecting it become different. I just don’t feel the procrastination and the sense of satisfaction after completing work, when I started loving and enjoying it become totally beautiful.

As this rule helped me to come out of procrastination. It’s just easy to implement and get the work done. It’s suggested by even great personality as mentioned before the Instagram co-founder Kevin Systrom. It’s effective for many so definitely do this 5-minutes rule and even it is very important to start loving and respecting your work. The satisfaction that your get of completing your work before sleep is worth of all the hard work that you have done from morning. A long time ago I read that “ A busy person has time for everything” but now I understood deep meaning of it and hope you too.

blogs.title: Does The Present Look Like The Future You Are Hoping For?
blogs.brief: Our present guides our day to day actions — and if they aren’t aligned with the future we want to create for ourselves, then we are aimless, directionless and spinning our own wheels.  I think two of the things that most people struggle with when it comes to creating a life that is true to them is this: (1) They don’t exactly know what they want and (2) life can be unpredictable, so how can you even decide where your day to day actions will lead?
blogs.content:
Does The Present Look Like The Future You Are Hoping For?

Pay close attention to your actions in the present moment.

While it’s important not to live for a future that you believe will ultimately make you happier, it’s vital that we pay attention to it so that we have a direction in our present moment to align with.

Our present guides our day to day actions — and if they aren’t aligned with the future we want to create for ourselves, then we are aimless, directionless and spinning our own wheels.

I think two of the things that most people struggle with when it comes to creating a life that is true to them is this: (1) They don’t exactly know what they want and (2) life can be unpredictable, so how can you even decide where your day to day actions will lead?

To address the first… We all know what we want deep down. The best way to find this answer is not to ask others for their opinion on what you should do with your life, but instead, get very still and quiet with a pen and paper in your hand, as you let the answers come to you naturally. It’s from my. ownexperience that when we give ourselves the space to fully digest problems without distracting ourselves, the answers you were looking for may be found from within.

In our society, we’ve been trained to need that quick hit of dopamine from our phones — but separating yourself from the constant need to distract yourself will be the game-changer you need on bringing more clarity and light to the life you ultimately desire to have.

As for number two… Yes, life is unpredictable. But while you may not be able to predict everything that happens in your life (and who would want to anyway?) you can still adjust the sails as you navigate the waters, so to speak. That is, begin taking action down the path you wish to go down and stay open to new paths revealing themselves to youon how to get there.

This was perhaps one of the greatest things I had to overcome — the thought of the unknown crushed me with self-doubt and prevented me from just taking action without necessarily needing to know HOW I would get there in the end.

The truth is — you don’t need to know HOW you’ll get there… You just need to know WHAT you want and trust yourself enough to know that you’ll figure out the ‘how’ part while you’re taking action on the way.

That intention is powerful and I hope that it guides you from here on out. Let this be the moment that you decide to get very, very quiet with yourself and ask yourself the tough questions…

Let this be the moment that you start taking intentional action towards what you want while ultimately letting go of the outcome. When you put the outcome on a pedestal, you automatically take the beauty out of the present moment which clouds the journey to get there and the only true thing we are able to expierence.

Let this serve as a reminder that nothing should stand in your way towards what you ultimately want. This is your life — so make the most most of it. Time won’t last forever, so take action now and figure out the rest later.

It will all come together in the end.

blogs.author: Diemut Metz
blogs.title: Age ‘Packages’ Are Bullshit
blogs.brief: I love perspective shifts. They’re like little surprises — I never know what it’s going to be or when I’m going to get it, but it always adds something special to my day.  Where did we all get the idea we’re a number? When? How did this happen?
blogs.content:
es — I never know what it’s going to be or when I’m going to get it, but it always adds something special to my day.

Where did we all get the idea we’re a number? When? How did this happen?

Right now, I’m 40. And being 40 comes with a ‘package.’ All ages inexplicably and invisibly come with a package. It’s what is expected of you at that particular age; what you’re supposed to be doing, who you’re supposed to know, where you’re supposed to have been, and… on it goes.

Come again?

We human beings love labels, don’t we? It’s how we organize and make understandable all the stuff that makes up our environment. And labels aren’t an inherent evil. They’re very quite useful. Just not when, I think, we boil ourselves down exclusively to them. That’s when we take the tool and start beating ourselves over the head with it instead of constructing something helpful.

So I’ve just fed fuzzbutt (my cat) and I’m about to have a shower, and my thoughts are ricocheting like greased lightning around my skull. In betwixt the fear of no one will ever be willing to hire me and this isn’t how my forty was supposed to be and how is forty supposed to feel? I still feel seventeen… it hit me like a semi going seventy pulling triples.

Hold the phone.

Yeah. How is forty supposed to feel? What’s it supposed to look like? When did I become a damned number? Who decided this?! The important question: Why the hell am I listening?!

Like timelines, age ‘packages’ are bullshit.

Timelines and age packages are based on the expectation of linearity. Neat, tidy, and in a straight line. Predictable and repeatable. Exactly as planned.

Someone, somewhere, at some point, decided this was normal. Which means this is acceptable. Which means, by default, that anything non-linear, anything punctuated equilibrium, anything done out of order, is abnormal. Which means, by default, it’s bad. It’s unacceptable.

Newsflash: Non-linear is different, not wrong.

(And I’ll almost certainly get back around to dissecting that on another day)

You know why this age-expectation thing really is most irrational? Because none of us know how long we truly have. We like to think we do, we measure it out like we do. We end up boxing ourselves in, pressuring ourselves, restricting ourselves, fitting ourselves into ‘packages’ — all so we can fit it all in on the timeline, by the right age.

The saddest part is we almost never consciously choose this. It’s something we pick up and that is instilled in us just by virtue of being a human in a human society. We inherit it every bit as much as we inherit our physical genetics. Just like our heartbeat and our breathing, it runs involuntarily, in our subconscious, until with this earth we part.

Some people might call me middle-aged. Am I? I could die tomorrow of a heart attack. Or I could live to be one hundred twenty-five. From that perspective, in neither case am I middle-aged. Why, then, should I live exclusively by the expectations of it, define myself by it; let my goals and dreams and desires be dictated by that?

I think when we’re living, without the weight of external expectations (especially when we’ve not, with self-awareness, thoroughly examined them): we’re reaching, growing, learning, doing. We’re free. And when we’re free, this is when we progress and succeed. We thrive. This is when the impossible becomes possible. In a sense: when you don’t know what you can’t achieve, you’re capable of achieving anything.

“Whether you think you can, or you think you can’t — you’re right,” — Henry Ford

And I know we can’t entirely escape it. And I will concede that some of the expectations are not without use as a general guideline. I just think we need to develop the self-awareness to consciously choose for ourselves what works for us and what works against us out of those expectations, and question even if those expectations have a valid purpose at all.

“In the end, it’s not the years in your life that count. It’s the life in your years.” — Abraham Lincoln

I am going to start consciously living as a person — a whole being — and not a number. I’m going to simply live.

From now on, I’m not (just) forty. I’m alive.

If you like my writing, please clap, follow, share and subscribe! I refollow everyone, provided you’re not a click-baity account. You can also follow me on Twitter!
Until next time… don’t do anything I wouldn’t do! 🙃

blogs.title: University Life Is Hard But I Love It
blogs.brief: University days for me was the most difficult but also the most amazing part of my life. That was the time when I learned the most life lessons and develop myself to the greatest capacity.  Like most freshmen, I had anxiety when I first entered this new chapter in life. I was so afraid that I wouldn’t be able to do well, couldn’t make new friends or adapt with a new environment, fail in any subject, couldn’t meet my expectation, disappoint the people around me, and so much more on my mind.
blogs.content:
University Life Is Hard But I Love It

University days for me was the most difficult but also the most amazing part of my life. That was the time when I learned the most life lessons and develop myself to the greatest capacity.

Like most freshmen, I had anxiety when I first entered this new chapter in life. I was so afraid that I wouldn’t be able to do well, couldn’t make new friends or adapt with a new environment, fail in any subject, couldn’t meet my expectation, disappoint the people around me, and so much more on my mind.

As soon as I entered the first semester, I felt like I almost dying. The system is completely different with high school life. I was almost gave up. Then what makes me decided to keep going? Here are the reasons.

  1. Grow Up Mindset. All this time life always gave me an easy way to go out from my problems and that’s why I grew up so slow. I never use 100% of my potential. Then come this big storm with great lightning and thunder — I mean university life. I felt like I was about to be thrown but I didn’t even try to stand still. I just wanted to stay away from that storm. Then this thought comes to my mind: if I run from my problem, I will never know how to overcome it, then why don’t I try to face it this time? Once I pass this storm, I will become stronger. But if I couldn’t make it, then I can learn a new strategy to overcome the next storm. That’s how I started to trust myself and grow up.
  2. Supportive People. I am so lucky to have the most supported people around me. My family, university colleagues, lecturers. I found it very important to have such support system around me. When I started to lose hope, at least there were people who still believed in me and gave me motivation. I only had like 12 classmates but we all fought together. The lecturers were willing to free their time to help me even after their working hours so I didn’t feel any pressure— you probably won’t find any lecturers like them anywhere.
  3. Life Lesson and Experience. University is not only about academic education. Everything that happened during my uni life really helped me to develop myself in various aspects. I learned to know myself better, how to deal with situations and people from different backgrounds, gained experience in communication, time management, how to build relationships, and many more.
  4. Achievement. For me personally, achievement can be a testament of my hard work and a sign where I know I have achieved my goal. What achievement did I get from university? The meaning of achievement to me is not limited to good grades or academic success, but so much deeper than that. Academically, I have finished my study and got a really good grade. But more than that, I found my best friends, unlocked new skills, was finally ready to face the world, and grew up.

After all the struggles, I couldn’t be more grateful to myself for making the decision to take the step into university life. I never regret it.

blogs.content:
What Happened to all my Friends?

Recently, one of my good friends from my undergraduate days came to visit me and passed the night.

We were roommates and close friends back in the days in FUTA. We met for the first time in 2007, during my first year at the secretariat of the campus fellowship we both attended, and he’s also an intelligent guy. He in fact, made the Dean’s list during his Diploma days.

The vagaries of life drove us apart for seven years after my graduation but I don’t think our recent reunion was a coincidence. I’m convinced that it was for a reason.

He laughed so much while here and he told me, "Victor please don't kill me this evening."

My sense of humour is a gift that endears people to me and which provides relief for me as well.

Then we began talking about friendships.

"What happened to all those friends you used to have back then in school? Has anyone of them got in touch with you recently?" I asked.

I saw the disappointing expression on his face. There was my answer.

"They are no longer in touch with me, even Samuel (who was his closet buddy back then) no longer calls me after he got married."

I smiled. "See, bro, it's normal. My ideas about friendships have evolved over the years."

All the friends I banked on during my university days fizzled. Even the one who was the closest to me and was mildly stabbing me in the back (yes, Kenny, I knew you were) still sees my account on Twitter, but his conscience wouldn't let him approach me again.

How do you ghost your friends in their difficult times and reappear when you perceive things are now good for them?

Why ghost people because they used the word “sorry” to you in a message. This happened to me and I’m not kidding.

Most of these secondary and university "friendships" I had seemed to have been doomed to fail anyway. These people hung around me on social media for one sole reason: so I would to parrot their ideologies back to them; they wanted to force me into their ready-made boxes but I refused to be pigeon-holed.

I refuse to erode my identity and individuality in order to appease anyone’s sentiment.

There were some friends whom I also ghosted when I slid into depression in 2014. I offer no excuse for my infractions, but at least, up to last year, I tried to reach out to some of them. Even an iceberg was warmer than their responses.

One, who had been my friend since 1997 has ghosted me (perhaps forever) and didn’t invite me to his wedding in 2017 because I removed him from my friend list in 2014.

It made me question if these people were ever true friends in the first place. It made me slow to form emotional bonds with people.

Because life offered some of them a step higher than I, they became too big for their boots.

Their memories was rearranged by fame. Even the one I reached out to help when no one would touch him with antiseptic gloves felt I no longer belonged to his clique because... Well, I was unemployed.

But these people still believe I’m the bad person. Perhaps they are right.

However, I reached a point in my life where I had no friend except one living miles away — someone whom I met via Facebook — whom I communicated with on phone. But you know, you can’t compare phone interactions with physical presence.

I struggled with depression, despair and rejection. My faith was shattered and my hope dwindled. With the last strength I had, in 2018, I deleted my old Facebook and Twitter accounts and created a new ones.

It was a time of personal rebirth. I no longer bothered about who was in my past, how many they were or what was going on in their lives. It was time to live life on my own terms.

I was now interested in meeting new people, having new friends and seeing reality from another perspective. I found a teaching job and began to mould back my self-confidence eroded by years of unbelievable disappointment and frustration.

My friendships worked this time around because I gave as much love as I received it.

I narrated this to my friend and added, "It’s time to break with the past and move into the new. They moved on with their lives, it’s time you moved on with yours."

Like a larvae that transforms to a moth, stop sulking and being bitter over friends of yesteryear who deserted you, make new friends.

Liberate yourself from that needless burden of "if it's not old friendship, it's fake."

Be open to new relationships; be open to new and exciting people.

No, put that phone down sometime and meet people in reality. That's another trap that social media has foistered on us: the replacement of real interactions with virtual illusions. Snap out of it.

Real friendships aren't always glamorous and airbrushed. They don't come with Snaptchat filters or Bobrisky's digital photoshops. They involve imperfect people leading imperfect lives.

Stop complaining about being lonely and bored if you are too afraid to be close to people and too distrustful to let them be close to you.

blogs.title: When You Are Lost
blogs.brief: The Devine Comedy posits that there are nine circles of Hell. Well, that’s probably because Dante wasn’t depressed. The fear, the self-loathing, and isolation all make the nine circles look like child’s play.  Depression makes it hard to function, and hard to do anything beyond breathing. blogs.content:
When You Are Lost

Depression can be difficult for both the person experiencing it and their loved ones.

The Devine Comedy posits that there are nine circles of Hell. Well, that’s probably because Dante wasn’t depressed. The fear, the self-loathing, and isolation all make the nine circles look like child’s play.

Depression makes it hard to function, and hard to do anything beyond breathing. It is often made worse when those around you don’t understand what’s wrong. The irrationality of emotions when it comes to depression makes it hard for you to understand yourself, but then others make you feel worse with their confusion.

How do you explain the unexplainable; that you’re crying for no reason, that the worries in your mind are insignificant but feel like the end of the world? Depression robs you of reality and leaves you stripped bare, drowning in a sea of insecurity and hopelessness, that you have no hope of escaping. Even when you look to others around you they often, through no fault of their own, make you feel worse.

It is not a good feeling to hear your struggles dismissed, even when they don’t mean to be dismissive. Saying, “I don’t know how to help you” when someone comes to you is not helpful, and may lead them down a dark path. As well, saying they should change their thinking is hurtful too, if they could think differently they would. When someone comes to you in crisis and you say these things, you push them closer to the edge. If you can do nothing else, you can listen and be empathetic, and if they still need help, research ways to help, and don’t be passive in their time of need. Sometimes, all they need is to see you take action, show that they matter to you and that you aren’t going to give up on them.

blogs.author: Olga Elisa
blogs.title: Let’s Talk about Outgrowing Relationships
blogs.brief: “I don’t get it, has something gone wrong? Has he/she changed?”  Do these questions pop up in your mind when you realize a close-knit relationship between you and someone just doesn’t feel like it used to anymore? Or worse, you start to self-criticize — “Is there something wrong with me? Why does he/she seem distant now?” (Yes, dear ENFP-INFP fellows, we hear you!)
blogs.content:
Let’s Talk about Outgrowing Relationships

“I don’t get it, has something gone wrong? Has he/she changed?”

Do these questions pop up in your mind when you realize a close-knit relationship between you and someone just doesn’t feel like it used to anymore? Or worse, you start to self-criticize — “Is there something wrong with me? Why does he/she seem distant now?” (Yes, dear ENFP-INFP fellows, we hear you!)

We often question, feel sorry, or even blame ourselves for a fading relationship with a friend, a spouse or an ex, even a family member. While we fully understand the inevitable fact that some people in our lives stay and some others leave eventually, sometimes we still can’t afford to see someone drifting away.

Some would say; “Well, life happens”, but what actually happens when it happens? Is this even normal?

Fading chemistry and outgrown relationships are unpleasant, and very uneasy to face, really. Some people would say that it is inevitable. But, is there anything we can do about it?

1. You’re not alone, it happens to everyone

Take a look at this point of view:

There were two birds, born and grew up together. Living and facing the same environment, they shaped and shared mutual values.
One day, they decided to explore the world outside their comfort zone, this time, they went separately. The first bird went to the north, and the second one flew away to the south.
Both met different challenges, different climates, and lived with different groups of ecosystems. Slowly, they reshaped their way of thinking and their values.
One summer day, these two birds flew back to their origin, and saw each other again.

What could possibly happen?

  1. They reunited, reminisced about the old days, and grew old together afterwards happily; or
  2. They reunited, realized how both of them now had different values and perspectives about life, then decided to drift away from each other.

Both are likely to happen, right? Maybe that’s what ‘life happens’ would look like.

We move forward, as do our values in life.

2. Why is it so common?

First and foremost, we should be aware that each of us is a single individual, who has different traits, identity, and personality. And in our lives, we grow within different surroundings, environments, values, and challenges. Those intrinsic and extrinsic factors really shape us, those make you — a unique self. And it’s never perpetual, it is and will always be dynamic. We evolve as life goes on.

We also have to admit that it really takes compatibility for individuals to keep getting along. The different stages of our personal growth and self-discovery take part in it.

At certain moments, our conscience would detect chemistry with another soul, and it also recognizes when we suddenly feel distant from our closest ones, maybe because we’re suddenly on different life phases. For instance, if one of you has become much busier than the other, or if you move out of town away from that person — the relationship could possibly just drift away.

So, yes, let’s just accept that life happens, and relationships — do evolve.

3. It’s okay to be upset, but no one’s to blame

You may be sad or mad at first, especially if you’re on the “being left” side. You’re allowed to feel what you’re feeling, because every feeling is valid. But your friend slash family slash partner’s feeling is also valid. At the end of the day, it’s not a competition and it’s important to be mature when we come across this kind of situation, because — like it or not, it happens multiple times in life. It’s not their fault to develop new values that they draw from college, and you’re not wrong to find politics are just plain unexciting and depressing.

You see, you shouldn’t view yourself as a victim. There’s no bad guy here. This “outgrowing a relationship” stuff is natural, and that person’s probably feeling a similar emotional turbulence as you are. It must be sad and confounding for both of you when the mutual feeling of love is still there, but the connectedness between you is dying out. Ultimately, both of you need to put your own selves’ best interest and personal growth first, even if it means leaving and hurting the other person.

As the saying goes, “Treat people the way you want to be treated” and “Before you judge, better you try putting yourself in someone else’s shoes first.” Before getting all worked up and offended, might as well use your empathy and imagine yourself walking in that person’s shoes, feeling unfulfilled while staying in a relationship that used to nurture and gave him or her comfort. Sooner or later, not leaving could adversely stick a wedge into the relationship instead.

4. “So should I talk it out or just leave it there hanging?”

We hear many “outgrowing relationship” stories out there don’t involve the talking — does it matter?

Well, no one likes being left without a word.. It leaves the other person to come up with ugly speculations, and perhaps a terrible heartbreak. So if it’s between lovers, there is no way you don’t talk about it. As for other relationships, it really depends on the circumstances.

Sometimes, a pair of best friends (or cousins) can suddenly drift apart without a word said, with no wild clash or unnecessary misunderstanding entails. In other cases, people feel betrayed, and a tight relationship can radically turn into a long cold war. So if you two seem to be cool with the sudden relationship fallout, and mature enough to take the subsiding bond as normal, you’re safe. But if you notice an unfathomable tension, you really should talk it over. Oftentimes we avoid this because it looks like it’s going to be awkward. True, it is going to be very weird and awkward. But clear communication is way better than avoidance, which is exactly the root cause of an irrelevant clash. Besides, there’s actually a chance that this person is willing to grow with you — so basically, put away assumptions, we never know.

According to some experts, our best first approach could be by carefully expressing how we feel to him or her, and be transparent on how you expect the relationship to go from there. Make sure there was no misperception and that you both agree to move on to the next phase — whether together or separately — like how grown ups should be.

5. Maintain a good relationship

Let go of grudges. While we know you’re not having the best time to find silver linings, and that not all doomed relationships end amicably, holding a grudge will do you no good — it messes with your mental health and possibly your immune system. .

No, you don’t need to force a relationship to last. Let go, and let it be however it is. Just cherish all the growth lessons you’ve learned together. Those up-and-down journeys you went through with each other were legit, and no one can take your memories together away from both of you. Acknowledge that this person was there in one of your darkest moments in your teenage years, or that he/she and their presence and support were parts of the rock that propelled you to stay standing and to eventually be here today.

So stay friendly, because there’s always a possibility that you’ll rekindle the close relationship you once had — maybe one day when you’re on the same page all over again. Or let’s say one day you’re on the brink of a burnout, then you start to reconnect with your childhood best friend because he or she is the only person who understands you and your limitations to the core. And hey, distance can actually bring two people closer because being away helps one better in self discovery. Who knows that after you move somewhere far, you start to build a deeper connection with your loved one more than ever.

6. “I suddenly worry about my current close relationships. What can I do so they don’t change in five years?”

As one ends, it opens the door for another one to blossom. When it comes to relationships (of any kind), the possibility is endless. It’s true that your closest ally today could be an estranged ex confidant in a few years from now — because nobody knows what will happen in the future, and this is a fact of life. No matter how hard you try, if it’s time to say goodbye, then it’s time.

The bottom line is.. “Hakuna Matata”. Throw out your worries about what’s to come and what will unfold in your relationship. Remember that hard times will make you become wiser, and sad times prepare you to embrace happier days.

Give your all to live in the moment, don’t let your anxiety make you overlook the blessings bestowed upon you, including those whom you love and love you back with everything you are at the moment. Our life’s made up of every walk we carried in the past, and the people that crossed our paths along the way. Focus in shaping the future we want, and for that matter, we rely so much on the people we surround ourselves with today.

So yes, be the best version of yourself and just be present. Remember; you are loved.

This article is a collaborative writing with a dear friend; Nadya Arviani, which is – honestly speaking – not a freshly brewed idea, as we've talked about doing this plan since a long time ago. 
Hope you enjoy this article.

blogs.title: AI & Law: The ABA Has This To Say About Lawyers Needing To Know About AI In The Law
blogs.brief: Most lawyers are aware that AI is an increasingly notable facet of society and our all-told daily lives. It is safe to suggest that few lawyers are particularly versed in how AI especially impacts the law and the practice of law. Probably even fewer lawyers are aware that the ABA has made pronouncements related to AI and the need for lawyers to become informed about AI as part of their duty of competence. We cover this herein.
blogs.content:
AI & Law: The ABA Has This To Say About Lawyers Needing To Know About AI In The Law

by Dr. Lance B. Eliot

For a free podcast of this article, visit this link https://ai-law.libsyn.com/website or find our AI & Law podcast series on Spotify, iTunes, iHeartRadio, plus on other audio services. For the latest trends about AI & Law, visit our website www.ai-law.legal

Abstract: Most lawyers are aware that AI is an increasingly notable facet of society and our all-told daily lives. It is safe to suggest that few lawyers are particularly versed in how AI especially impacts the law and the practice of law. Probably even fewer lawyers are aware that the ABA has made pronouncements related to AI and the need for lawyers to become informed about AI as part of their duty of competence. We cover this herein.

Key briefing points about this article:

  • AI has become an everyday topic of discussion and is pervasive in our daily lives
  • The field of law and the practice of law is increasingly having AI-infused too
  • It would seem that not many lawyers are yet up-to-speed about AI in the law
  • Few realize too that the ABA proclaimed (kind of) a duty of competence related to AI
  • Here is a look at what the ABA says about AI and what lawyers ought to be doing

Section 1: Introduction

What comes to your mind when I mention AI?

It seems that you would ostensibly have to be living in a cave to not be aware that AI is a hot topic these days and that our everyday access to and dependence upon high-tech is becoming increasingly infused with AI. In some instances, this AI augmentation is welcomed, while in other cases the AI has opened Pandora’s box of concerns over computer-based laden biases and inequities.

I would dare assert that most lawyers have heard about AI, along with potentially being subjected to AI-running programs that have impacted their personal lives. For example, perhaps a lawyer seeking a home loan perchance ran afoul of an AI-based mortgage lending app that opted to turn them down for their desired loan. Or maybe a lawyer has used an AI-powered app to help do their annual taxes and tax filings.

That being said, the realistic odds are though that relatively few lawyers are aware of how AI intertwines with the law and the practice of law.

Yes, sadly, lawyers are often so focused on the daily treadmill of generating billable hours that they have little time or energy to be thinking about AI in the law.

You might be therefore interested in knowing what the ABA has to say about lawyers needing to know about AI in the practice of law. In short, lawyers are supposed to know about the present and future of AI in the law. Ironically, of a sort, not only don’t lawyers generally know about AI In the law, but they are also unaware that they are supposed to diligently know about the topic, as so proclaimed for their complying with the official lawyering standards and practices promulgated by the ABA.

That’s a double whammy, namely not knowing about AI in the law and additionally not knowing that they are supposed to know about the very thing they don’t know about (a tongue twister and conundrum, for sure).

For a wide range of details about what is occurring in terms of AI and the legal world, both good and bad, see my book available on Amazon entitled “AI and Legal Reasoning Essentials” at this link here: https://www.amazon.com/Legal-Reasoning-Essentials-Artificial-Intelligence/dp/1734601655

Let’s start by briefly identifying how AI comes to play in the practice of law. After doing so, we will take a close look at the ABA stated indications on this lawyering ought-to-know topic.

AI in the law is still in its infancy. Initial steps consist for example of using AI-based Natural Language Processing (NLP) to parse legal text and attempt to interpret the legal meaning and legal nuances in everyday legal contracts. AI advanced search techniques and technologies are being utilized during e-Discovery to analyze large datasets and narrow down the key portions that human attorneys ought to be closely scrutinizing.

And so on.

You can bet your bottom dollar that AI is already starting to be found in and will largely eventually overtake the high-tech used to do case management, contracts development and upkeep, discovery, client interaction and communique, court prep and trial assistance, legal research and analyses, etc. Inch by inch, those applications and so-called LegalTech will embody AI capabilities that make the software easier to use and take on some portions of the lawyering task at hand.

All of those aspects are dealing with the application of AI to the practice of law.

There is yet another side to the AI-in-the-law coin.

You see, there are two major ways to mix together AI and the law: (1) AI as applied to the law and the practice of law, (2) Law as applied to the advent of AI. Thus, lawyers need to be ready and competently able to use AI within their law firms and throughout the adjudication process. Plus, lawyers need to become knowledgeable about the laws and governance related to AI systems and be able to proffer sound legal advice accordingly to their clients that are using or impacted by AI systems.

Okay, that sets the stage for the overarching indication by the ABA pertaining to this matter.

Here’s what the ABA has summarily stated: “RESOLVED, That the American Bar Association urges courts and lawyers to address the emerging ethical and legal issues related to the usage of artificial intelligence (“AI”) in the practice of law including: (1) bias, explainability, and transparency of automated decisions made by AI; (2) ethical and beneficial usage of AI; and (3) controls and oversight of AI and the vendors that provide AI” (per American Bar Association, House of Delegates, Resolution adopted on August 12–13, 2019).

Some attorneys, upon reading this ABA pronouncement, will merely shrug their shoulders and contend that since the resolution merely “urges” lawyers (an interpretatively soft phrasing) this allows for more than enough leeway to stridently argue that it is altogether a vague and weakly worded declaration, meaning that no sane lawyer has to worry about the proclamation.

Case closed.

One supposes that you could choose to ignore the ABA statement if you desired to do so. Furthermore, you could likely also use as an escape hatch the claim that you didn’t even know that the resolution existed (it is admittedly rather obscure, somewhat hidden from conventional view). In that sense, you can use the infamous variant of the Chewbacca defense that ignorance is bliss.

A contrary view is that taking such a stance could be construed as a wink-wink momentary avoidance tactic, such that eventually you’ll need to get familiar with AI in the law, and meanwhile will blindly tread along realizing that it is just a someday (maybe) item on your pending To-Do list.

Section 2: More To Say And More To Know

As further meat to the bones, as it were, the ABA also published an article entitled “Artificial Intelligence And The Law: The ABA’s Important And Timely Contribution” which came out around the same timeframe as the posted resolution (the article was published on August 26, 2019).

On a related tangent, a quick question that might come to your mind is whether the ABA statement and the corresponding ABA article are still worth their salt, given that they were posted in 2019. The answer is absolutely and abundantly yes. The same foundational points made in 2019 are equally of importance today.

As a small caveat, I would politely suggest that there are even more topics to be encompassed, due to the further advances made in AI and the practice of law, but the earlier narrative is still viable and fully apt.

The ABA article provides a slew of questions that AI-astute lawyers ought to know how to respond. Here are some of those meaty questions for you to consider: “Questions abound: to what extent may my clients use impenetrable, potentially biased algorithms to make determinations that assess or affect customers or unsuspecting citizens? What should they disclose? What representations can my clients fairly make about the AI solutions they market? Should my firm use AI in recruiting? Is AI more accurate than conventional approaches in complying with data subject access requests under GDRP and CCPA? Can I sufficiently trust AI in e-discovery to make representations to the court — or to determine case strategy?”

Speaking of lawyer competencies, the ABA article notes this: “The resolution correctly recognizes, referencing Rule 1.1 of the ABA Model Rules (Duty of Competence), that attorneys must ‘be informed, and up to date, on current technology.’ It also underscores that attorneys ‘cannot be expected to know all the technical intricacies of AI systems.” (per the ABA article).

Ponder for a moment the latter part of that quotation.

One of the easiest excuses used by lawyers that are aiming to look the other way when it comes to learning about AI In the law consists of exhorting that they don’t have the time and nor inclination to learn the technical intricacies of AI. That seems like a bona fide excuse. But, either that excuse is based on a false understanding of what they need to actually know, or it is a cleverly devised sidelining argument to distract from the crux of the matter.

The point is that lawyers do not need to know about the technical intricacies of AI and ergo it is a false pretext to bandy around.

Knowing the technical intricacies is decidedly not what the intention is and nor is it a necessity either. Instead, the notion is to ensure familiarity with what AI consists of, what its limits are, how it is used, how it is improperly used, all within a legal context. No need to delve into bits and bytes, and no need to carry around a screwdriver or high-tech-related accouterments.

Of course, to further clarify, lawyers are welcomed to dig more deeply into AI and discover the technical intricacies, if of interest and relevance to their personal and professional interests (this is not a requirement and should not be alleged as such).

One final point for now.

The ABA article rightfully posits a serious criticism of a kind about the ABA pronouncement. Recall that the resolution is notably succinct, and as such has a severely lacking element: “But it falls short of asking a crucial question: What constitutes evidence of competence for use of AI in the legal system?” (per the ABA article).

Section 3: Conclusion

Sometimes, something that is short and sweet is not enough. To add teeth to the matter, the hope is that the ABA will ultimately stipulate particulars concerning AI-related lawyering competencies. Until then, lawyers are on the honor system.

You can choose whether to abide by a classic wait-and-see attitude, only being dragged into AI in the law when the dangling sword of compliance becomes clearer, or perhaps you’ll be forced anyway into the AI-in-the-law tsunami as you are swept along by your peers and the courts and society all told.

At this juncture, the choice is yours as you see fit.

blogs.title: Big Tech and AI ethicists — a reciprocal duty to engage?
blogs.brief: A couple of months ago I was invited to join Mark van Rijmenam, aka The Digital Speaker, and Dan Turchin, Co-founder and Chief Executive Officer of PeopleReign, in their “Between Two Bots” podcast. This podcast features “data revolutionaries who are leading the new field of AI ethics, establishing new regulatory frameworks for AI, and reimagining the role of government as tech companies increasingly act as autocrats”.
blogs.content:
Big Tech and AI ethicists — a reciprocal duty to engage?

A couple of months ago I was invited to join Mark van Rijmenam, aka The Digital Speaker, and Dan Turchin, Co-founder and Chief Executive Officer of PeopleReign, in their “Between Two Bots” podcast. This podcast features “data revolutionaries who are leading the new field of AI ethics, establishing new regulatory frameworks for AI, and reimagining the role of government as tech companies increasingly act as autocrats”.

Mark and Dan always start the talk by discussing three articles. The first article we discussed was named “How Big Tech dominates AI ethics group”. Its main claim is that Big Tech has a very big influence on the EU AI regulation. In 2018 when the European commission set up a high-level expert group, almost half of the experts (i.e. 26 out of 56) came from ‘the industry’, whereas only six people represented civil society. The article is skeptical about this and also implicitly criticizes Luciano Floridi, a well-known Professor of Philosophy and Ethics of Information at the University of Oxford with “long-standing ties to Big Tech”. Mark and Dan asked:

“What do you make of the fact that Big Tech is part of the committees which advise regulations? Do you consider this to be a problem?”

Here is an edited version of my answer.

The influence of Big Tech on policy-making is certainly a problem in an industry, which is dominated by an oligopoly and where all the players from the oligopoly are involved. That’s an unfortunate circumstance. But beyond the mere numerical question of ‘how many big tech representatives were there? And how many civil society representatives were there?’, it raises the basic question for anyone else present whether you want to engage with Big Tech or whether you want to contain it.

I studied International Relations, a few years after the Cold War had ended, and there we learned that in the Cold War, the US oscillated between ‘containment’ and ‘engagement’ with the Soviet Union. The same distinction comes into my mind in the discussion about how to deal with Big Tech: some people treat Big Tech like an enemy whose influence should be contained, while others are very happy to engage with Google, Facebook & Co.

Beyond questions of accepting funding, the article specifically raises the question whether or to what extent Big Tech should be included in policy-making. Now, we certainly don’t want to have our policy dictated by Big Tech but I would argue as follows:

if there was a choice between having Big Tech sitting on the table or having them lobby for their business interests behind closed doors, I’d rather have them on the table.

The article quotes someone who says “’money does not necessarily change someone’s viewpoint, but there is ’self-selection’”. By this he means that some researchers will still attend an expert roundtable also when funding from Big Tech is involved, while others will stay away because they’re too critical.

I personally think it is important to go there even if [or actually: right because!] Big Tech is there, and even if you are critical of Big Tech. One could even go as far as to claim: it is your responsibility to go there and you must not abstain from this responsibility. [NB: Because, after all, you are an expert, and we, i.e. the non-expert people who care about AI ethics policy-making, but don’t have the competence or authority to participate, need people like you to represent our interests].

However, critics sometimes go as far as to denounce all people who work within Big Tech and who are doing AI ethics on a corporate level. Those who engage on AI ethics in Big Tech are sometimes discredited by other voices who say things like “you’re being co-opted; you can’t be taken seriously as an AI ethicist”. But in my opinion, we need to be able to integrate ethics into Big Tech and for that matter we need people who take care of it in these companies. Of course, AI ethics also needs to be assessed from the outside, but that alone will never be sufficient. And outside the corporations, we could think of a division of labor between different AI ethics advocates. I imagine the AI ethics landscape to be comparable to what we have with NGOs in sustainability. There you have e.g. WWF who cooperates with almost any company they can find, then you have Greenpeace who are much more more critical, and finally you have Extinction Rebellion who you will never find on the table because they are outside on the street where they chain themselves to traffic lights. We need different stances of criticism but we also need some people who are willing to talk to the big influential players. Because what Big Tech says in such consultations at least gets publicly heard and they can be held accountable for what they say in those context.

Listen to the entire episode to hear our discussion on the other two articles: With Robotics4EU, the EU wants us to believe in responsible AI robots; and Machine Learning, Deep Fakes, and the Threat of an Artificially Intelligent Hate-Bot.

Find the full podcast episode on the following platforms:

https://youtu.be/kZA4qf4vOWs

https://vimeo.com/665049818

https://betweentwobots.com/episodes/ep06-dorothea-baur

blogs.title: The future of Healthcare is Digital
blogs.brief: I wouldn’t be surprised if someone says the future belongs to the digital world. But when it comes to healthcare, I can see how the existing issues are targetted by the internet & digital gadgets to revolutionize the entire sector. The healthcare that you know is shifting from a non-digital to a fully digital domain and this article explores the shifts that the industry is experiencing.
blogs.content:
The future of Healthcare is Digital

Probing the current issues in the healthcare sector and possible solutions that will drive the sector in the long term

I wouldn’t be surprised if someone says the future belongs to the digital world. But when it comes to healthcare, I can see how the existing issues are targetted by the internet & digital gadgets to revolutionize the entire sector. The healthcare that you know is shifting from a non-digital to a fully digital domain and this article explores the shifts that the industry is experiencing.

Demand Vs Supply

Like every other industry, the supply of healthcare services is also short as compared to the global demand. Even more disturbing is the fact that the services are unevenly distributed. This affects the earning of healthcare professionals and creates a disturbance in smooth healthcare adaptation to society.

Unlike other sectors, the demand in healthcare cannot be predicted by mathematical models and statistics alone. They need sensors and real-time data. Also, the needs are generally always urgent, and thus waiting is not a sustainable option for the industry.

There are two major needs of the industry:

  1. Healthcare professionals
  2. Healthcare products

The addition of healthcare professionals requires huge time & effort. 4–5 years of education followed by 5–10 years of on-site training is required by an average healthcare professional and thus this is the part where no short-term solution can be provided to fix the issues.

The second need of “Healthcare products” can be provided by targetting the supply needs and setting up manufacturing facilities. But in the event of non-availability of the right demands, the manufacturing facilities have to bear the high cost of research and long waiting times. This pushes the cost of products on a higher side which cannot be afforded by a large majority of the population.

How digitization is shifting the industry?

Prediction of healthcare needs

The addition of sensors (such as Blood pressure, heart health, SpO2, chemical sensors, machine vision) can accurately identify the upcoming medical issues. This creates a large pool of datasets that is reliable and can generate demand.

More and more people are using health sensors. Roads, factories, parks, schools, etc. are being fixed with chemical, thermal, health sensors and machine vision powered CCTVs to track the population in real-time. This creates an accurate health metric of the existing population.

The predicted health metrics can be used by the organizations to subscribe to necessary medical services. The demands can be used by governments to add new courses in educational institutions, order new equipment, and train new professionals directly depending on the need.

Distribution of healthcare services

Distribution is simply a game of mathematics if the demands are known. But that is true for other industries. In healthcare, distribution is impacted by timings. Thus, the integration of services to the internet is the only sustainable solution.

The availability of products, doctors, and other services on the internet empowers patients to make informed decisions. It eliminates the life lost due to data unavailability and creates a chance of utilizing resources to their maximum level.

E.g. Hospitals and medical care centers are using the usage data of medical equipment of the buildings and scheduling the equipment in real-time. It creates profitability for the business and a single piece of equipment can save more lives.

Adding Robots to the existing pool of healthcare professionals

While a Robot is no substitute for a human being but in absence of trained healthcare professionals, the sensors, robots and other digital tools are really helpful.

Machine vision systems are helping doctors and nurses to monitor high-risk patients without any 24*7 manual presence.

AI & Machine vision systems are helping doctors diagnose ailments in a more accurate manner. The availability of drugs, issues on a certain group, and effectiveness on a certain condition are also predicted by the collected data on existing patients.

In the past few months, robots have been used to transport medicine and other supplies to highly contagious patients thus limiting/ reducing direct contact of the healthcare professional to these patients.

Integrating the financial industry in healthcare

The insurance and banking industry has already adopted the digital wave and this creates enables patients to buy health insurance online. The availability of a list of hospitals, small premiums comparable with benefits offered by the insurance is promoting the public to buy insurance.

People can take loans easily via their phones with the prescription offered by the hospital and thus avail services and pay later. This is enabling a large population that did not have access to the insurance.

Lastly, there is a strategic shift going on in the healthcare services with the industry moving towards subscription model. We will cover that in our next articles.

blogs.title: The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Employment: How Many Jobs Will Be Lost?
blogs.brief: The future of employment is a hotly debated topic, and the emergence of artificial intelligence (AI) has only fueled the fire. With AI continuing to develop astoundingly, many wonder what this means for jobs; will they disappear? Will people be able to find work with their new robot overlords? Or will AI help provide new employment opportunities? Let’s go through some ways AI will affect employment and how you can get started learning about it today.
blogs.content:
The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Employment: How Many Jobs Will Be Lost?

The future of employment is a hotly debated topic, and the emergence of artificial intelligence (AI) has only fueled the fire. With AI continuing to develop astoundingly, many wonder what this means for jobs; will they disappear? Will people be able to find work with their new robot overlords? Or will AI help provide new employment opportunities? Let’s go through some ways AI will affect employment and how you can get started learning about it today.

What is artificial intelligence?

Artificial intelligence is programming a computer to decide for itself. For instance, we have seen smart robots and many computer software capable of performing tasks requiring human intelligence. It is predicted that artificial intelligence will do more and more jobs in the future than humans currently do, which raises the question: how many jobs will be lost to artificial intelligence?

Who will benefit from AI, and who will lose out?

For the future of AI, there are many unknowns. But one thing is sure: AI will majorly affect employment in the upcoming future. Some jobs will be lost to automation, while others will be created. So, who will benefit from AI? And who will lose out? The answer is everyone and no one. The changes brought by AI will challenge some employees’ skill sets, making them less desirable to employers in the future and requiring them to retrain or adapt their career paths accordingly. They are more likely to see new job opportunities if they upgrade their skill set or learn to take on different responsibilities in their current roles — and artificial intelligence may create new jobs that we can’t even imagine today because of its effect on technology and society. We know that every industry stands to gain or lose something as this remarkable technology continues its rapid progress and adoption across all sectors of society.

What careers should people consider in an AI economy?

Many people will inevitably lose certain jobs in an economy driven by artificial intelligence. But what careers should people consider? Here are four suggestions for career paths that might exist in a future AI economy.

1) Development-oriented careers like software engineers, data scientists and computer programmers who are charged with making sure all the technical aspects of an AI-driven world work smoothly and efficiently;

2) Service-oriented careers like designers who specialize in human-machine interfaces and customer service agents who deal with the more emotional side of interactions between humans and machines;

3) Innovative fields like social psychologists and cognitive anthropologists study the effects of robots on humans and how humans will use robots to help them meet their needs. Policy-oriented experts who negotiate or govern relations between humans and machines.

5) Creative thinkers from other fields — journalism, psychology, philosophy — to help us grapple with this unprecedented situation.

How can I prepare for this change and stay relevant in the industry?

The future of artificial intelligence is shrouded in uncertainty. But despite the lack of clarity, there are a few things we can do to prepare for this change and stay relevant in the industry. Some professions will be more affected than others. For example, a report by Gartner predicts that by 2020, one-third of today’s jobs will be replaced by software or robots, with most jobs being eliminated in the next ten years. However, it’s not all bad news. New roles will be created that may not have existed before because of advancements in AI technology. Professionals who adapt now to these changes can thrive during the revolution and take advantage of opportunities where they emerge.

blogs.title: How to Improve Your Self Image
blogs.brief: How to Improve Your Self ImageHow to Improve Your Self Image
blogs.content:
How to Improve Your Self Image.

It’s important to concentrate on your concerns.

When you don’t feel good about yourself, it can cause problems in your life. Here are some tips to help you feel better about yourself. Stop saying bad things about yourself and start looking at the things you do every day that make you a wonderful person. If you don’t feel good about yourself after spending time with someone, you need to cut back on the time you spend with them. Switch to neutral statements that don’t hurt you instead. Changing your look can give you a new lease on life and make you feel better about yourself.
